ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Glial Hypertrophy (Intra-axial brainstem lesion)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: MRI shows enlargement of medulla/pons/cerebellum consistent with glial hypertrophy; stability over 1 year supports this over aggressive glioma.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Brainstem Glioma
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: MRI findings of intra-axial lesion could represent a glioma, though lack of progression makes hypertrophy more likely.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Acoustic Neuroma
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Unlikely due to normal hearing sensitivity, normal speech recognition, and presence of normal ABR Wave II (generated by auditory nerve).

ordered_list.rationale_short: Assess speech recognition abilities and check for rollover.
Evaluate reflex pathways for retrocochlear or brainstem pathology.
Assess neural integrity of the auditory pathway given NF diagnosis.
Assess cochlear outer hair cell function.
Evaluate central processing abilities (dichotic rhyme and digits).
MRI to visualize brainstem structures and rule out acoustic neuroma.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Peripheral hearing sensitivity and cochlear function are normal. However, there is significant evidence of brainstem dysfunction, including absent contralateral reflexes, abnormal ABR (absent/degraded late waves with preserved early waves), and mildly abnormal central auditory tests. MRI confirms an intra-axial brainstem lesion (glial hypertrophy) consistent with the patient's neurofibromatosis.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Normal hearing sensitivity bilaterally (0-10 dB HL across 250-8000 Hz).

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: Normal word recognition scores (96% bilaterally); no rollover observed.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Normal ipsilateral reflexes (500-2000 Hz); absent contralateral reflexes bilaterally (500-4000 Hz).

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.result_summary: Abnormal. Left: Normal waves I-III, absent IV-V. Right: Wave V reduced (<50% of I) or absent at high rates. Poor morphology at 60 dB nHL despite normal hearing.

tests.name: Otoacoustic Emissions (OAE)
tests.result_summary: Robust responses bilaterally (>20 dB SPL), consistent with normal cochlear function.

tests.name: Central Auditory Tests
tests.result_summary: Mildly abnormal for age. Dichotic Rhyme: Left 27%, Right 67%. Dichotic Digits: Left 70%, Right 80%.

tests.name: Radiology
tests.result_summary: MRI showed enlargement of the upper medulla, pons, cerebellum, and thalamic areas, consistent with glial hypertrophy or brainstem glioma.

proposed_items: Monitor for tumor growth or progression via serial MRI and audiologic evaluation.
counseling_actions: Explain that normal hearing sensitivity coexists with brainstem pathway dysfunction.
Clarify that findings are consistent with known neurofibromatosis/glial hypertrophy rather than a new acoustic tumor.
Highlight that stability of findings over one year is a positive prognostic sign.
Reinforce the importance of academic support due to potential processing speed and complex listening difficulties.

escalation.rationale_short: Patient is already diagnosed and stable; continue routine monitoring of the brainstem lesion.

follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor for progression of the brainstem lesion and functional status.

expected_outcome: Repeated radiologic studies performed over the course of 1 year have shown no progression.
The ABRs recorded over 1 year were consistent with the radiology and with the patient's symptoms in that there has been no significant change.
She is generally functioning on grade level and is doing reasonably well.
